awd_titl_txt: Understanding Employment Trajectories of Racially Minoritized Engineering PhDs
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite well-funded efforts to diversify engineering in the United States, Americans who identify as Black, Latinx, and Indigenous (Native American, Alaskan, or Hawaiian) remain underrepresented and marginalized throughout engineering academic training and employment. Previous research has identified that underrepresented PhD-degreed engineers of color are less likely to be employed in engineering jobs compared to their overrepresented counterparts. However, there is much less certainty on the reasons behind this disparity. Moreover, the employment paths of White women in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) employment have been extensively explored along with the career trajectories of graduate students of color in STEM, but there has been very little attention to engineers of color with PhDs post-graduation. The focus of this research is to understand the employment paths for two populations: underrepresented engineers of color who have successfully navigated the challenges of obtaining an engineering PhD, along with Asian engineering PhD holders who are well-represented in the field. This research will investigate two critical factors that can help explain disparities for underrepresented engineers of color: (1) their experiences of racialization, and (2) their interest in using engineering as a mechanism to decrease social inequities. This research will address the gap in understanding the factors that drive these disparities in engineering employment outcomes across racial groups and how to decrease them, thereby aiding engineering education and industry communities in becoming and remaining more diverse, innovative, and affirming. 

The researchers will answer these questions through a mixed-methods design, including a longitudinal survey component and qualitative in-depth interviews. Survey respondents will be engineers of color who are working in industry and the academic workforce within a decade of graduating with their PhD. Participants will be recruited through the professional networking site LinkedIn as well as professional organizations for engineers of color. In the first phase, survey data and analysis, using structural equation modeling, will determine how respondents' experiences of racial inequity and bias at work and their motivations and efforts to address social inequities through engineering vis-a-vis their employers, predict their employment outcomes (e.g., commitment, intentions to quit) by increasing their "job embeddedness." The analyses will test this model across different race groups. Collecting follow-up employment data one year later will provide a measure of actual persistence. Survey findings will inform the content of the qualitative interview protocol. Interview participants will be people of color with an engineering PhD who are not directly using their engineering skillset because they either switched from an engineering job into a non-engineering job or transitioned into a leadership or administrative position. These findings will help to identify why engineers of color with advanced doctoral training are either: (a) dissatisfied and pushed away from this workforce or (b) persist in their work to transition into different roles that allow them to diversify the field. Insights from this research will inform workplace training webinars promoting diversity and inclusion in engineering workplaces in both industry and academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Brief Project Outcomes Report:

  • · Award Title: Understanding Employment Trajectories of Racially Minoritized Engineering PhDs
  • · Federal Award ID: 1916534
  • · Report Submission Period: 07/01/2022 to 06/30/2023

 

Our project scrutinized the intricate forces that shape the career trajectories of racially minoritized engineering PhD holders. We focused on two prime aspects: their racialization experiences (comprising discrimination, microaggressions, and tokenism) in professional settings and their commitment to using engineering as a force for social justice and racial equity. We aimed to comprehend how these factors influenced their workplace engagement and consequently shaped their persistence in the engineering sector.

 

Methods Employed:

From 2022 to 2023, we adopted a mixed-method approach merging both survey and interview data. Our survey collated insights from 554 participants spanning diverse engineering sectors, including industry, academia, and government. We also carried out comprehensive interviews with 54 women of color who hold engineering PhDs and work in various STEM fields. The data from these methods delivered the following notable findings:

 

Racialized Challenges Across Sectors

Engineers from racially minoritized backgrounds encountered higher instances of workplace discrimination and tokenism across all engineering sectors. These racial incidents correlated with diminished job embeddedness, causing them to feel less integrated into their organizations and less likely to view their jobs as core to their identities.

 

The Dual Nature of Equity Ethics 

Our research disclosed the dualistic nature of "Equity Ethics" among racially minoritized engineers. On one side, a robust commitment to racial equity correlated with an enhanced sense of belonging and a passion for social justice. Conversely, this commitment also linked positively to experiences of workplace discrimination and tokenism. Essentially, encountering race-based discrimination may have amplified their resolve to foster racial equity in their workplaces.

 

Persistence Factors 

For racially minoritized engineers, elements such as a sense of belonging, job embeddedness, and the perceived significance of their work were crucial in predicting their career persistence. This finding was especially prominent in the industry sector, where feelings of exclusion and undervaluation raised the probability of contemplating job transitions.

 

Mentorship and Commitment to Equity Ethics

Qualitative interviews with women of color in engineering underlined the critical role of mentorship in surmounting professional obstacles. Participants secured mentorship through pre-existing connections, networking, and independent learning. The interviews also highlighted their firm commitment to social impact and community development, steered by "Equity Ethics". They are devoted to progressing towards racial equity by dismantling systemic inequalities, inspiring future generations, contradicting stereotypes, and fostering equitable and inclusive futures in their individual fields.

 

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impact

Our research unravels the distinct experiences and challenges encountered by racially minoritized doctoral engineers. It emphasizes the crucial role of equity values in steering their career trajectories. The findings underline the urgent need for customized support and equitable practices to nurture diverse and inclusive environments within the engineering sector. Beyond the realm of academia, this research acts as a potent call to render professional environments more inclusive and racially fair.
